title: Introductory lecture to radionuclide separation techniques

author: Marko Štrok, Reaktorski center, Institut "Jožef Stefan"

segmentation: Hello, my name is Marco and in this lecture I will make introduction to reading class separation techniques.
After sampling and pre treatment we have to separate already and quite of interest.
Separation protocols may include selective precipitation, an exchange chromatography, liquid liquid extraction, extraction, chromatography, distillation.
Combination of mentioned protocols or some other protocols.
Which separation protocol we will use depend on the analyte interfering cranial clouds and sample matrix selective.
Reputation is debate on how to separate radionuclides one from another based on the differences in solubility at different chemical conditions.
This enabled that one radio Clyde stays in solution, another is precipitated in this lobby.
Simple, the contention or filtration can be then employed to separate the soft rain and clouds from precipitated.
Typical examples are separation of strontium from calcium with fuming nitric acid or separation of radium from let at specific page by forming barium.
Extraction chromatography is nowadays often used in real chemistry for the separation of several radionuclides.
It employs organic extractant incorporated into the inert resin packed in the column.

This enables that radium type of interest is extracted from the solution when passing to the column and later on diluted using collusion media, at which attention of radiant light of interest is reduced.
Examples are commercial resin from Micron, such as new Terra for anium separation diva for thorium, separation and ASR resin for strontium and lead separation.
